oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Clifton Place
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Detail of the exterior west elevation looking southeast of Clifton Place. Shows the front of the two-story brick house. The house has a two-story portico consisting of four Ionic columns and an Ionic pediment.

Clifton Place, named after the Clifton Turnpike, was the antebellum home of General Gideon J. Pillow (1806-1877). The original Greek Revival style home was built by Nathan Vaught in 1838, and the home had several later additions. During the Civil War, it was confiscated by the Federal government, but it was returned to General Pillow after the war.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Eason, W. Jeter
